responses:
theorem Topology.P1_inter_of_P1_and_isOpen {X : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] {A B : Set X} :
    Topology.P1 A → IsOpen B → Topology.P1 (A ∩ B) := by
  intro hP1A hOpenB
  intro x hxAB
  rcases hxAB with ⟨hxA, hxB⟩
  -- `x` lies in the closure of `interior A`
  have hx_clA : x ∈ closure (interior A) := hP1A hxA
  -- Since `B` is open and `x ∈ B`, we have `x ∈ interior B`.
  have hx_intB : x ∈ interior B := by
    simpa [hOpenB.interior_eq] using hxB
  -- We will show that `x` is in the closure of `interior (A ∩ B)`.
  have hx_goal : x ∈ closure (interior (A ∩ B)) := by
    -- Use the neighbourhood characterisation of closure.
    refine
      (mem_closure_iff).2 ?_
    intro U hU_open hxU
    -- Consider the open set `U ∩ interior B`, which contains `x`.
    have hV_open : IsOpen (U ∩ interior B) := hU_open.inter isOpen_interior
    have hxV : x ∈ U ∩ interior B := And.intro hxU hx_intB
    -- Because `x ∈ closure (interior A)`, this open neighbourhood
    -- intersects `interior A`.
    have hNonempty :
        ((U ∩ interior B) ∩ interior A).Nonempty :=
      (mem_closure_iff).1 hx_clA (U ∩ interior B) hV_open hxV
    -- Extract a point `y` witnessing the non-emptiness.
    rcases hNonempty with ⟨y, ⟨hyU, hy_intB⟩, hy_intA⟩
    -- `y` lies in `interior A ∩ B`, hence in `interior (A ∩ B)`
    -- because `B` is open.
    have hy_intAB : y ∈ interior (A ∩ B) := by
      -- `interior (A ∩ B) = interior A ∩ B` since `B` is open.
      have hEq :
          interior (A ∩ B) = interior A ∩ B :=
        (interior_inter_isOpen_right (A := A) (B := B) hOpenB).symm
      have : y ∈ interior A ∩ B := by
        refine And.intro hy_intA ?_
        -- `y ∈ interior B` implies `y ∈ B`.
        exact interior_subset hy_intB
      simpa [hEq] using this
    -- Thus `U` intersects `interior (A ∩ B)`.
    exact ⟨y, And.intro hyU hy_intAB⟩
  -- This is exactly the requirement for `P1 (A ∩ B)`.
  exact hx_goal
